posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked:
Is there any function to detect when a motor is stalled?

Did anyone use a function like this, and did it work reliably?
Check for near 0 rpm or high current draw.

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: Have you tried checking if velocity is below a certain threshold and current is above some threshold?

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: We’ve tried detecting when the velocity is low, as well as using current and applied voltage, but it hasn’t seemed reliable.

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: What edge cases have you ran into?

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: It just doesn’t seem to be reliable; sometimes we slip, sometimes it doesn’t detect.

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: I’d add a time threshold and use stator current. Apart from that I don’t have other ideas

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Check for low rotor velocity and sustained current draw at the same time.  Nothing else causes this.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
GalDotan:

It just doesn’t seem to be reliable; sometimes we slip, sometimes it doesn’t detect.

This adds some complications, because that’s not a stall condition. That’s a “heavily loaded” condition.

In a strict sense, You can still check for this by comparing “expected speed” vs “actual speed” ratio, and/or “free spin current” vs “applied current”.

For intake processes, lowering the current limit can be an effective way to reduce the maximum potential output power, allowing this action to actually stall. Now you can clearly read the current draw and velocity; Once it stalls and momentum drops to zero, it’ll probably stay that way, and you’ll get a clear reading.

If you’re doing a homing process and accidentally slipping belts or chains… definitely lower the current and then try again. You can always up the current afterward for high performance motions.

posts.name: Sidd Rao
posts.cooked:
Try and use a denouncer to make sure your trigger is consistent for a certain amount of time before actually doing the action. This will remove a lot of false positives and make your detection a lot more accurate.

WPILib has an in built denouncer that you can use, here are the docs for it:

A debouncer is a filter used to eliminate unwanted quick on/off cycles (termed “bounces,” originally from the physical vibrations of a switch as it is thrown). These cycles are usually due to a sen...
